awd_titl_txt: Partial Differential Equations and Several Complex Variables
awd_abstract_narration:
Two of the most important equations in several complex variables  are the Cauchy-Riemann equations and the induced  tangential Cauchy-Riemann equations. The understanding of these equations have been the focal point of research in complex analysis in the past few decades. The problems addressed in this project include 
the Cauchy-Riemann equations and the tangential Cauchy-Riemann complex on complex manifolds, especially on   complex projective spaces (which is compact and with positive curvature)  and negatively curved manifolds.  Understanding the  geometric aspects of these equations under the  curvature  conditions  and their relations with  function theory in complex manifolds   are some of the most  challenging and important  problems  in complex analysis and geometry. The study of several complex variables in a geometric or non-smooth  setting has provided interesting new questions   with fresh insight to problems in   topology,   foliation theory, complex dynamics,  algebraic   and complex geometry. Complex geometric   theory  has only just begun to develop and   Shaw will continue her efforts in this direction. She will also continue her research on applying  the geometric measure theory and harmonic analysis to several complex variables for non-smooth domains. 


Since the pioneering work of Poincare and Hartogs more than a century ago,  the field of  several complex variables has played a major role in modern mathematics. The use of  partial differential equations has been  the main tool  for studying  several complex variables, as well as complex geometry  in the past few decades. The broader impacts  from the proposed activity  are that  these problems are at the intersection of analysis,  geometry and topology  with applications  in applied mathematics and physics.  Other than the mathematical areas described in the proposal,  recent progress in the Dirichlet and Neumann problem on nonsmooth  domains has found applications in other disciplines like physics and engineering. The Hodge theorem is an extension of the classical  Dirichlet Principle, the canonical solution to the energy minimizing problem arising  from the heat transfer problem. Recent applications of the theorem on domains with corners and wedges have been used  in electrokinetics  and other fields in engineering and physics. The PI will use all of these ideas in her work mentoring students and the writing of a text that makes some of these partial differential equations topics more accessible to a wider range of mathematicians, especially those working in geometry and complex analysis.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
The PI has continued her efforts in understanding the central problems in several complex variables in the geometric setting. She has been reaching out to mathe- maticians in other areas to collaborate on solving some of the most intriguing and fundamental problems in complex analysis and geometry. These problems arise from complex geometry and it is naturally related to solving the Cauchy-Riemann equations under the geometric curvature conditions. The difficulty of the problems poses some of the most challenging and exciting new directions in several complex variables. The PI and her collaborators have made substantial contribution to the understanding of the subject in the past few years. They have discovered new sur- prising phenomena for the Cauchy-Riemann equations in complex manifolds. Based on these new results, she has been invited to give lectures on the subjects all over the world in many countries in both conferences and short courses.

Interaction among complex analysts and differential geometers has produced deep and important problems and results over the past few decades. The PI has brought the necessary tools and knowledge in both disciplines to make contributions in both areas. She also continues her work on the Laplace equations on domains with minimal smooth boundary, which is not only an active area of research in mathematics, but has applications in engineering and physics.

The PI is also co-authoring a graduate textbook to be published by the American Mathematical Society. This book will be a bridge between complex analysis and complex geometry and partial differential equations, based on her own lecture notes and research in the past decades. She has already made many chapters of the book available to graduate students and researchers. She has been the the Coordinating Editor of Analysis for the Proceedings of American Mathematical Society since 2008. She has also serves as associate editor for the Journal of Geometric Analysis. 

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2015
Modified by: Mei-Chi Shaw
